job_title: IT Helpdesk Technician in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Fast paced environment Daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly expectations understood due to the nature of working at a school.
cons: Hard to climb the ladder

pros: The faculty truly engage with and care about the students
cons: The administration regularly puts untenured, junior faculty into positions of departmental leadership because those faculty have less security to say no to the admins. Upper administration is antagonistic to faculty needs and concerns. President is among the highest salaried presidents for any university of a similar revenue stream, but the faculty salaries are well below average. The push for graduate programs to grow without resources and accept unqualified students is unethical. We simply cannot support a graduate program in the sciences with the lack of labs and funding for research. The medical school seems to do it, but the rest of campus simply can't. And even the medical school faculty talk to us and seem to have concerns about the quality of their MS program that it is just a tuition generator and most of the students don't get the experience they would at a school with resources. The recent push towards a more "catholic" presence is concerning. I understand that we are a catholic school, but not allowing the LGTBQ groups to put up Pride Week displays in the library is not following our own Franciscan values.

review_title: Toxic Environment, Inept Leadership, Teetering on Collapse
pros: There are no pros. A completely toxic and hostile environment. I’ve never experienced anything remotely close to this in my professional experience. What should be a mission driven institution has instead turned its back on its Franciscan heritage and liberal arts education.
cons: Leadership openly lie and harass faculty, ignoring their own handbook and eliminating programs and positions in mid-year. They keep faculty busy with endless strategic restructuring initiatives that are then routinely ignored and rejected by admin, but faculty are unable to focus adequate time on teaching or research because of meaningless assignments and tasks. Faculty and staff are overworked and exhausted. Admin play favorites and share private personnel info with their lackeys to create a culture of juvenile bullying. No one questions the university president, his decisions that have caused catastrophic challenges (a junior college that has never come close to enrollment goals, a statewide online prep high school that has only enrolled 4 students, a new engineering building for a new engineering program despite existing engineering programs being completely saturated, micromanaging, etc). This place feels more like a cult interested in celebrating one outsized personality than being a legit institute of higher learning. Admin have earned a reputation for short sided and foolish decisions. Admin flat out refuse to address issues related to a lack of diversity and inclusion. Pay is lower than comparable institutions. Faculty and staff don’t know who they can trust. Majors and reporting structures routinely change without notice or input. Faculty and staff are fleeing. This place is a black mark on any CV. Even the surrounding community distrusts this university and residents have started a petition against it. Avoid.

pros: Nice co workers and free food
cons: Poor pay , little advancement opportunities.

pros: Outside of my work group employees were very nice and inclusive Pretty Campus After 90 days you can take free online classes-downside they do not have any computer science courses.
cons: I was badly treated by my boss. They treat women poorly. Manager frequently worked from home but want staff to be there every day and would talk poorly about coworkers. Was hired to do a job that I had no experience with and they understood that and then let me go for lack of execution. Promised training but was only given outdated One-Notes to learn from. Promised a letter of recommendation that was reneged on. The turn over with staff is crazy high. Parking is terrible, you will likely have to walk or take a shuttle to get to work. If you are not Catholic thy will constantly try and convert you. You may feel uncomfortable if you’re not religious, large meetings begin with a prayer. Human Resource department was not helpful during exit.

pros: People I worked with and taught, and the office where we worked was great.
cons: Poorly run programs where we spent money too fast before next budget. Also, the ELL program wasn’t so well managed by top, and the way or reason for our teaching was just funding and teaching for tests. Not useful at all.

pros: Communication, networking, database management, fundraising. Flexible hours.
cons: Some tasks can be very repetitive.

pros: Employees enjoy free parking. Most people are friendly.
cons: Pay is below market average. Tech is probably a decade if not more behind. Until recently, vacation and sick leaves or other requests are all paper.

review_title: Potential for flexibility and passion, but ultimately an unsupportive and unsustainable environment for most.
job_title: Advancement Services Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Depending on the department and supervisor of the role, flexibility in place (work from home or at the office) is available. Solid health care plan and good PTO for entry/mid-level jobs. Knowledge that you’re contributing to creating opportunities for students and communities alike.
cons: Generally speaking, the university leadership maintains a culture entrenched in white supremacy with no real indication of interest in critical reflection on this, much less actually working to change things. The president has been there for over 20 years now, and received a 70% raise ($535K to $899K) between 2017 to 2018. Meanwhile, staff turnover is incredibly high in no small part due to the low wages they pay essentially everyone else. As recent as 2021, a new employee with a master’s in the field they were working in at Marian started at $42K. The president’s salary remains above $900K as of 2020. Leadership pays lip service to “dignity of the individual,” one of the guiding Franciscan Catholic values, but is hardly doing anything to demonstrate they’re committed to that in reality. The president and upper leadership keep pushing “growth” in ways that the infrastructure of the university isn’t actually ready for. The lack of documented policies + procedures and understanding between departments of who does what is very minimal.

pros: Positive culture, small, good mission
cons: Underpaid, unrealistic responsibilities, high turn around rate, burnout

pros: Autonomy, flexibility in your schedule
cons: The pay is below market

pros: great way to meet and share stories at marian
cons: can be treated poorly. i had four bosses in the time i was there. not a safe work space at times

pros: Some folks at MU are great and are dedicated to student success and to working hard - but they are few and far between - and they usually quit after a couple years
cons:
> Leadership cares only about ego and increasing the reputation of Marian - not about growing / improving the internal infrastructure needed to support big moves
> President is oblivious to most campus operations and only cares about his 'pet' projects -most programs are ignored and underfunded / under supported 
> Administration regularly pays lip service to "Franciscan values" and supporting staff but falls far short of delivering any real support - most departments on campus are understaffed and most employees are overworked and underpaid - the entire University (especially high function departments like business/finance, athletics, student success, etc) should have 25-35% more staff and employees regularly leave for equivalent jobs due to better pay and more respect from their superiors
> Zero opportunity for career advancement 
> Hard-workers are not recognized and non-performers are rewarded

pros: This is a great place to grow your soft skills while building your resume.
cons: HR is a difficult hoop to jump through at Marian.

review_title: Some good, some not so good....
pros: Very nice campus and students, some staff members are really dedicated and do great work.
cons: Way too much nepotism here. Managers/directors in some departments will hire their kids, their spouses, or close friends over properly credentialed, experienced, and qualified individuals. I have seen someone replace a highly qualified long-time employee with their family member and in a few other cases their close friends. It is really out of control here and reduces the qualify of the education students receive. Really a shame as it used to be different. I am surprised the HLC does not care people don't have the proper credentials and credit hours in subjects to teach them.

pros: Good pay and flexible schedule
cons: Politics get in the way.

review_title: Too many cons and not enough pros
job_title: Mid Level Management in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Most of the low and middle level people are good people to work with and trying their best
4 weeks "vacation"
Opportunities to gain a lot of experience
Beautiful campus to walk around
cons:
Very low compensation compared to similar roles in the area (25-30% less)
Very high churn rate makes for a very inexperienced workforce and a very stressful and, at times, toxic environment
Work/life balance is non-existent (almost everyone gets a company phone and are expected to respond to calls and emails around the clock and on holidays)
Extremely high turnover as people get burnt out and leave, after about 3-4 years typically (multiple departments had almost completely turned over in the time I was there, 85% churn or slightly higher)
Senior management is out of touch and resistant to new ideas
Some senior management make sexist and homophobic comments/jokes.

pros: Franciscan values are the foundation for students and faculty.  Good reputation of a local university.  New medical school of osteopathy.  Above national average for the NCLEX nursing pass rate.  Great president, Dan Elsener.
cons: Pay is poor for the experience required to teach.  Power struggle issues within our department.  The lots of inconsistency and not much notice of changes in courses assigned to teach.  Staff development opportunities are not available - there should be resources to improve teaching skills.

pros: I have a couple of great office mates who make the day fun and the environment supportive. No micro-managing. This is due in part to the fact that everyone is simply too busy and carrying too heavy of a work load to have time to micro-manage.
cons: For the most part everyone is quite nice. But it's a good ole boys club for sure, dominated by a President who is focused solely on growing the athletic department.  Also, that niceness is typically due to extremely passive and meek personalities. If you have a strong personality, are a go-getter, highly involved in other professional areas....you will not fit in and will experience frustration and lack of understanding. A lot of alums work here and so you see what a mediocre education will get you....no drive, no foresight, no ability to problem solve. Just good old midwestern values, keep your nose to the grindstone, carry a heavy work load, don't make waves. High turnover of really good people while the meek stay forever! I have also seen huge mismanagement of money and questionable financial aid "policies". They talk a big game with their Franciscan values but I assure you, they do not walk the walk.

pros: Good marketing, some decent career opportunities, can be laid back.
cons: Low pay, declining enrollment, shockingly high turnover,  lots of management and staff with little experience outside of Marian, very heavy workload, a lot of superficial people in HR and management, poor upper management, very short tenure across the board leading to little knowledge of processes.

pros: Lots of opportunities to try new things. Colleagues are fantastic, and supportive. The students are terrific.
cons: There are times when work load is very arduous. Sometimes people leave and are not replaced for years. Raises are very low.

pros: Great retirement program, pretty good vacation and holiday schedule, I like my fellow peers for the most part.  Good president
cons: Operates like a proprietary entity, upper management will do whatever is best for the company and has no regard for the employee.  Cannot trust HR

review_title: One of the most toxic work environments I've ever been in
pros: Students and faculty colleagues are great.
cons:
The administration cannot take any kind of constructive criticism and treat faculty like their enemies. When they do faculty surveys and don't like the results, they talk about needing to get rid of "bad apples." Deans ask for advice about how to do a better job, and then tell the faculty that they aren't engaged and that they are the problem. Research requirements for professors teaching four classes per semester (often with 4 preps) make for a very stressful work environment. Women, in particular, have a hard time advancing at Marian (several women were denied tenure in the last 3 years, but no men were). All the men in the administration are paid substantially more than the women, which can be verified through public records.  There is severe micromanagement and no support for the  core curriculum. The administration only cares about money, not about preserving the dignity of individuals. They even knocked down the convent where nuns from the founding order lived in order to build graduate student housing. That sort of behavior makes Marian a Catholic school in name only. Instead, the administration worships the almighty dollar, and yet the school is millions and millions of dollars in debt. It's very unstable. 

But the worst thing is the way that the administration bullies the faculty. It treats everyone like they are expendable and uses fear to keep people in line. I wouldn't work there again if I were paid double the money. Having left, I feel like I've finally been restored to sanity.

pros: The people i worked with were very nice and easy to get along. The work itself is very technical and required me to constantly walk around to solve issues. I enjoyed it quite a lot.
cons: The medical school staff can be rude and a little difficult to work with.
